Storage

Suitable for various types of data, economical and reliable cloud storage, provides a high assurance of security, lasting and stable storage, and the capability of rapid and flexible expansion.

Apply for a trial Purchase now

Azure Storage is a kind of highly durable, available and scalable cloud storage enabling access anytime, anywhere.

We charge customers Azure storage space fees according to the storage capacity, number of storage transactions (number of read and write operations performed in the store) and data already transmitted.

Storage is divided into five types:

Block Blob: Block Blob is a cost-effective, scalable method that can be used for reliably storing mass Blob data. Typical instances include: data sharing, mass data and backup.

Documents: Documents allows VM of Azure Data Center to install shared document systems by SMB agreement, and access the document system via the standard Windows file API. The virtual machine can be connected to these document systems simultaneously, permitting you to easily share permanent data between different roles and instances. You can also access your data using Windows file API or document REST API.

Page Blob and disk: Page Bloc provides block storage for random access and frequent updating/optimization. Thanks to high performance, durability and reliability, it can be used as the permanent disk of VM in Azure.

Tables: Tables are a kind of highly scalable and easily available NoSQL database. These provide storage-based key values for structured data and semi-structured data.

Queue: Queue provides a reliable message transfer system used to plan asynchronous tasks, and realizes permanent message transfer.

In addition, we provide four redundant storage levels:

Local redundant storage (LRS): we maintain multiple copies of data in a zone so as to provide high durability.

Geo-Redundant Storage (GRS): we provide asynchronously extra data durability through replication between two zones hundreds of miles apart in the same territory. In two zones, we maintain multiple copies of data.

Read-Access Geo-Redundant Storage (RA-GRS): in addition to GRS services, we provide read-only access to the storage account in the auxiliary zone (which has the final edition consistent with data in the main storage system). When the storage account in the main zone is not available, customers can use this service to access the data.

Zone Redundant Storage (ZRS): in addition to storage of three copies like LRS, the zone redundant storage space will replicate data asynchronously between data centers of one or two zones, so as to improve the durability of LRS.

Azure hosting disk is a new and recommended disk storage product used for Azure virtual machine, enabling permanent data storage. Multiple hosting disks can be used for every virtual machine. Hosting disks provide two types of lasting storage options: advanced hosting disk and standard hosting disk.

If you’re interested in the pricing details of non-hosting disk, please refer to the Non-hosting Disk and Page Blob pricing details page.

Advanced Hosting Disk

Advanced hosting disk, based on SSD, aims to support I/O intensive workloads, with extremely high throughput and low delay. With the help of advanced hosting disk, we can set a permanent disk and configure its size and performance characteristics.

The total expenses of advanced hosting disk depends on the disk size and quantity, and is subjected to the outgoing data transmission. The disk size provides different input/output operations per second (IOP), throughput limits and monthly price per GB. We can select most appropriate options including storage size, IOP and throughput. We can add several permanent disks onto the VM and configure at most 64 TB of storage space to every VM. The disk throughput of every VM can reach up to 80,000 (input/output operations) and 1600 MB/second, with a read delay of less than 1 millisecond. Advanced hosting disk is supported by the sizes of the DS Series, DSv2 Series and FS Series VMs exclusively used for advanced disk.

Operation and Data Transmission Pricing

If the transactions of Page Blob are not performed by a virtual machine, billing is done by the transaction. For every transaction, a single operation shall be considered as write, read or delete for billing. If the size of the read or write is more than 64 KB, an extra read/write (IO) expense will be charged for every excess of 64 KB, and 15 IO expenses are charged at most for every transaction. If the size of transactions is more than 1 MB [64 KB x (1 transaction + 15 IOs)], other IOs are not charged irrespective of the size of transactions.

Data redundancy options

Local Redundant Storage (LRS) Make multiple synchronous copies of data in a Data Center.
Zone Redundant Storage (ZRS) Store three data copies in multiple data centers in a region or across regions.
Geo-Redundant Storage (GRS) The same as LRS, it also allows to store multiple asynchronous copies into the second data center hundreds of miles apart.
Read/Access Geo-Redundant Storage(RA-GRS) The same as GRS, it allows to read and access the second data center.

To learn more about the redundancy options and how to use these options to obtain high availability, please check the replication page of Azure storage space. Please note, not all redundancy types are suitable for all storage types.

FAQs

Expand all

Common

  • If I only use the storage service for a few days a month, is the cost prorated?

    Yes. The storage capacity is charged by the average data storage (GB) per day within a month. For instance, if you’ve used 10 GB storage capacity continuously in the first half of the month, but haven’t used any storage capacity in the second half of the month, the average storage usage will be billed at 5 GB.

  • How do I know which data redundancy option I am using (see the text above)?

    You may select redundancy in creating storage accounts. After creation, you may check the redundancy by using Azure Portal or the service management API.

Blob Storage

  • What is a Blob storage account and what are the differences between this account and a general-purpose storage account?

    Blob storage account is exclusively used as the storage account for Blob storage data, such that the customers can assign access layers according to the data access frequency in the account. A general-purpose storage account can be used for storing Blob, documents, disks, tables and queues.

  • Has the price of Block Blob in the general-purpose storage account been changed?

    No. The price of Block Blob in the general-purpose storage account hasn’t yet been changed. Please check the Block Blog Pricing page.

  • When checking the Azure bill, how can we distinguish whether paying for the Blob in the Blob storage account or general-purpose storage account is required?

    If “Hot” or “Cold” will be in the resource name, meaning this expense is related to the Blob storage account. For instance, if it’s “Standard IO - Cold Block Blob (GB)”, it means you used the Blob storage account and need to pay for this account, while “Standard IO – Block Blob (GB)” is charged in relation to the Block Blob in the general-purpose storage account.

  • What are “Hot” and “Cold” access layers and how do we ascertain which one is to be used?

    In the Blob storage account, we could set the Blob’s access layer to “Hot” and “Cold”. The storage GB price increases in the sequence of “Cold” and “Hot” layer. The data access expense increases in the sequence of “Hot” and “Cold” layer. The “Hot” and “Cold” layers are separately applied to data with almost no access and occasional access, and the availability service level agreement of these data has a lower requirement. If you don’t know the data access mode, it’s recommended that you should use the “Hot” layer for at least one month in the beginning, then decide if it’s necessary to shift to “Cold” storage to save costs where applicable.

  • Is paying the data write expense of switching a Blob storage account from “Cold” to “Hot” required?

    We will charge the data retrieval of the Blob storage account when it’s switched from “Cold” to “Hot”. For instance, if the Blob storage account has 100 GB data, when the account is switched from “Cold” to “Hot”, you will be charged with a data retrieval fee of 100 * RMB 0.0657 = RMB 6.57.

  • Is paying for data writes required when the Blob storage account is switched from “Hot” to “Cold”?

    No. Paying for data writes is not required when your account is switched from “Hot” to “Cold”. If you write directly data into the “Cold” access layer of the Blob storage account, only paying the data writing expense is required.

  • What is the charge for Geo-replication data transfer?

    When you write data into a GRS account, the data will be replicated into another Azure Zone. The Geo-replication data transfer charge refers to the bandwidth cost of replicating data to another Azure Zone.

Disk Storage

  • If I add the empty 100GB disk onto my VM, do you charge me the entire 100 GB expense or just the cost of the storage space I used?

    If the empty 100GB disk is supported by an advanced storage account, you will be charged with the expense of a P10 (128GB) disk. If you use any other types of storage account, only the storage space for storing data written into the disk will be charged, irrespective of the allocated disk size.

  • Does the service level agreement cover advanced storage, the same as other storage services?

    Yes. 99.9% read/write availability also applies to advanced storage accounts.

Hosting Disks

  • If I add an S10 or P10 disk to the VM, do you charge me the cost of the total amount shown above or just the cost of the storage space I used?

    The allocated disks are charged at the same rate irrespective of the disk space used.

  • The price shown is the monthly price. How do you charge if the hosting disk is used less than 1 month?

    The charge uses the monthly price according to the hours and proportional cost.

Document Storage

  • If I create sharing with a 5 TB limit, do you charge me for the entire 5 TB or just the cost of the storage space used?

    Only the storage space used is charged for, rather than the allocated limit.

Support and Service Level Agreements

If you have any questions or need help, please visit Azure Support and select self-help service or any other method to contact us for support.

We guarantee that at least 99.99% (99.9% for the cold access layer) of read requests for data from read-access geographic (RA-GRS) will be successfully processed, provided that data writing failures from the primary zone are retried in the secondary zone

We guarantee that data reading requests from local redundant storage (LRS) and geographically redundant storage (GRS) accounts will be successful at least 99.9% of the time (99% for the cold access layer).

We guarantee that data reading requests from local redundant storage (LRS) and geographically redundant storage (GRS) accounts will be successful at least 99.9% of the time (99% for the cold access layer), as well as read requests accessing remote geographically redundant storage (RA-GRS) accounts.

To learn more about the details about our service level agreement, please visit the Service Level Agreements page.

The hosting disk itself doesn’t provide a service level agreement with financial support. The availability of a hosting disk depends on the service level agreement governing the basic storage used and the virtual machine it’s attached to. To learn more about the details of the service level agreement of the hosting disk, please visit the Hosting Disk Service Level Agreements page.
